/datasets/ljspeech/processed_wavenet/ljspeech-mel-07244.npy|Now, the lower forms of amphibians, such as siredon, menobranchus, siren, etc.,

/datasets/ljspeech/processed_wavenet/ljspeech-mel-07247.npy|Now this is the permanent, mature condition of many amphibians,
/datasets/ljspeech/processed_wavenet/ljspeech-mel-07250.npy|the highest order (anoura) of this class. Thus, then, in ontogeny the fish goes no further than the fish stages.

/datasets/ljspeech/processed_wavenet/ljspeech-mel-08025.npy|Organization of the Motorcade
/datasets/ljspeech/processed_wavenet/ljspeech-mel-08026.npy|Secret Service arrangements for Presidential trips, which were followed in the Dallas motorcade,
/datasets/ljspeech/processed_wavenet/ljspeech-mel-08027.npy|are designed to provide protection while permitting large numbers of people to see the President.
/datasets/ljspeech/processed_wavenet/ljspeech-mel-08028.npy|Every effort is made to prevent unscheduled stops, although the President may, and in Dallas did, order stops in order to greet the public.
/datasets/ljspeech/processed_wavenet/ljspeech-mel-08031.npy|Motorcycles. -- Dallas police motorcycles preceded the pilot car.
/datasets/ljspeech/processed_wavenet/ljspeech-mel-08032.npy|Manned by officers of the Dallas Police Department, this automobile preceded the main party by approximately quarter of a mile.
/datasets/ljspeech/processed_wavenet/ljspeech-mel-08033.npy|Its function was to alert police along the route that the motorcade was approaching and to check for signs of trouble.
/datasets/ljspeech/processed_wavenet/ljspeech-mel-08034.npy|Motorcycles. -- Next came four to six motorcycle policemen whose main purpose was to keep the crowd back.
/datasets/ljspeech/processed_wavenet/ljspeech-mel-08035.npy|The lead car. -- Described as a "rolling command car," this was an unmarked Dallas police car, driven by Chief of Police Curry
/datasets/ljspeech/processed_wavenet/ljspeech-mel-08036.npy|and occupied by Secret Service Agents Sorrels and Lawson and by Dallas County Sheriff J. E. Decker.
/datasets/ljspeech/processed_wavenet/ljspeech-mel-08037.npy|The occupants scanned the crowd and the buildings along the route.

/datasets/ljspeech/processed_wavenet/ljspeech-mel-08610.npy|On November twenty-two, however, before surrendering possession of the rifle to the FBI Laboratory,
/datasets/ljspeech/processed_wavenet/ljspeech-mel-08613.npy|"Lifting" a print involves the use of adhesive material to remove the fingerprint powder which adheres to the original print.
/datasets/ljspeech/processed_wavenet/ljspeech-mel-08614.npy|In this way the powdered impression is actually removed from the object.
/datasets/ljspeech/processed_wavenet/ljspeech-mel-08615.npy|The lifting had been so complete in this case that there was no trace of the print on the rifle itself when it was examined by Latona.
/datasets/ljspeech/processed_wavenet/ljspeech-mel-08617.npy|Day, on the other hand, believed that sufficient traces of the print had been left on the rifle barrel,
/datasets/ljspeech/processed_wavenet/ljspeech-mel-08618.npy|because he did not release the lifted print until November twenty-six, when he received instructions to send "everything that we had" to the FBI.

/datasets/ljspeech/processed_wavenet/ljspeech-mel-08621.npy|The print's positive identity as having been lifted from the rifle
/datasets/ljspeech/processed_wavenet/ljspeech-mel-08622.npy|was confirmed by FBI Laboratory tests which established that the adhesive material bearing the print
/datasets/ljspeech/processed_wavenet/ljspeech-mel-08623.npy|also bore impressions of the same irregularities that appeared on the barrel of the rifle.
/datasets/ljspeech/processed_wavenet/ljspeech-mel-08624.npy|Latona testified that this palmprint was the right palmprint of Lee Harvey Oswald.
/datasets/ljspeech/processed_wavenet/ljspeech-mel-08626.npy|fingerprint expert with the New York City Police Department, conducted an independent examination and also determined that this was the right palmprint of Oswald.
/datasets/ljspeech/processed_wavenet/ljspeech-mel-08628.npy|In the opinion of these experts, it was not possible to estimate the time which elapsed between the placing of the print on the rifle and the date of the lift.
/datasets/ljspeech/processed_wavenet/ljspeech-mel-08629.npy|Experts testifying before the Commission agreed that palmprints are as unique as fingerprints for purposes of establishing identification.
/datasets/ljspeech/processed_wavenet/ljspeech-mel-08630.npy|Oswald's palmprint on the underside of the barrel demonstrates that he handled the rifle when it was disassembled.
/datasets/ljspeech/processed_wavenet/ljspeech-mel-08631.npy|A palmprint could not be placed on this portion of the rifle, when assembled, because the wooden foregrip covers the barrel at this point.
/datasets/ljspeech/processed_wavenet/ljspeech-mel-08632.npy|The print is additional proof that the rifle was in Oswald's possession.

/datasets/ljspeech/processed_wavenet/ljspeech-mel-09968.npy|During the evening of November twenty-two, the Dallas Police Department performed paraffin tests on Oswald's hands and right cheek
/datasets/ljspeech/processed_wavenet/ljspeech-mel-09969.npy|in an apparent effort to determine, by means of a scientific test, whether Oswald had recently fired a weapon.
/datasets/ljspeech/processed_wavenet/ljspeech-mel-09970.npy|The results were positive for the hands and negative for the right cheek.
/datasets/ljspeech/processed_wavenet/ljspeech-mel-09971.npy|Expert testimony before the Commission
/datasets/ljspeech/processed_wavenet/ljspeech-mel-09972.npy|was to the effect that the paraffin test was unreliable in determining whether or not a person has fired a rifle or revolver.
/datasets/ljspeech/processed_wavenet/ljspeech-mel-09973.npy|The Commission has, therefore, placed no reliance on the paraffin tests administered by the Dallas police.
